column4: Well I am using kvm and virt-manager on my headless vm server.... I have two phsical hd's and one is partitioned into sections that I want my vm's to run on so they are not running on the same drive that is running the actual vm server.... does that make sense?
I always feel so dirty and used when I ask questions in the main channel...

No what I mean is this... Won't i loose performance if I am running a vm server and vm's on the same hd because they are both using the same spindle? Wouldn't it more efficent if I have my vm's on a seperate drive ?
Which comes to my real question... I want to point to this other drive to create my vm's on but can't seem to find a method to do this...
but others said not to as they are still unreliable
I do have sda3 support too
create a new storage pool with virt-manager and relocate the vms disk image there
So I can just relocate the image there?
if you have the vm disk images as a image file its just remove that drive from vm and relocate it (you might need to refresh storage pools) and then add the image back from the new pool

You mean if I allocated it? I did not allocate the space I just created a image... So I located the image and move it to a temp folder than create a storage pool with the 2nd hard drive and copy the image onto that drive?
That's what I have been told too
and since this was a server running a business didn't want the trouble
yeas, just copy the file to new location, where the new storage pool is
